content.description: Start on the less-than-vertical right face. Establish any way you can with your hands below the obvious jug. Move up to the jug and then to the edge for the topout.
content.location: It is on the slabby face to the right.

content.description: Start matched on a jug on the very far left corner of the boulder. Establish and move your right hand to a decent crimp, and then bump to a good edge. Adjust your feet, and cross your left over to a slopey dish on the lip. Continue right to better holds and then the easy topout.(Note: the upper lip has not been cleaned at the very start of the problem. It flows better to stay on the lower holds at the beginning of the climb.)
content.location: It is on the very far left side of the boulder.

content.description: Start as for Clean Slate, but move right off of the triangular crimp to the slopey arÃªte. Make tricky moves up to the lip for an easy topout.
content.location: It is on the right side of the blank face.

content.description: Clean Slate is the obvious, short and sweet line straight up the blank main face. Start matched on the triangular crimp towards the right side of the face. With awkward feet, throw for a decently incut, half pad crimp just below the lip. Stick the deadpoint, adjust your feet, move to the lip, and top out.
content.location: It is to the right side of the blank face.

content.description: Slate Rock is a slightly overhung, clean slate with 4 routes of beginner-intermediate difficulty. It is definitely worth checking out.
